content: Petros Dellaportas has a joint appointment as a professor in Statistical Science in the department of Statistical Science, University College London, and as a professor of Statistics in the department of Statistics, Athens University of Economics and Business.
summary: Petros Dellaportas has a joint appointment as a professor in Statistical Science in the department of Statistical Science, University College London, and as a professor of Statistics in the department of Statistics, Athens University of Economics and Business.

summary: Developing tools to identify abnormal data events (and fraudulent behaviour) in the VAT transactions network.
title: Detecting anomalies in the VAT network

summary: Improving the ability of widely used economic forecasting models to deal with volatile changes such as those caused by financial crises.
title: Forecasting with large macroeconomic and financial datasets

summary: Contributing to the analysis of event sequence data through a novel mechanistic modelling framework for marked spatiotemporal point processes.  Other members of the project are Ioannis Kosmidis (PI) and Aristeidis Panos (post-doc)
tags: Poisson processes for  identity systems and cyber-security
title: Poisson processes for identity systems and cyber security

summary: We apply modern statistical and ML methods for probabilistic fault detection and power forecasting using SCADA data from wind turbines.
title: Probabilistic fault detection and power forecasting in Wind parks

summary: We consider the problem of inverse reinforcement learning in an economic environment where the agent is a consumer who maximises their utility by choosing what to consume and is constrained by how much they can afford.   The project is funded by just-eat plc and the results have immediate applications in retail, aviation and hotel industries.
title: Recovering Utilities from observational data

summary: The  project  contributes  to  the  existing  research  on  finance-macro  linkages  by  investigating whether  new techniques in machine learning,  namely reservoir computing,  can be applied in a novel way toi mprove macroeconomic modelling.  The research team consists of Petros Dellaportas (PI), Sophie Van Huellen (co-PI), Juan-Pablo Ortega and Lyudmila Grigoryeva.  It is funded by EPRC.
title: Reservoir Computing for Macroeconomic Modelling
